content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear and solvable in short time.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one
Every distance in output is 2 times larger not 4 (only area is 4x larger). So you should fix the Statement and output section

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this contribution, the testcases are enough to see whats going on too

I agree with the others, the statement could be a little bit clearer, even though one could do just fine with only the tests.
And so, since it's so easy to understand it with the tests why not just give a quick example as statement.

Some possible ideas for the wording:
You are given a 2D array M of size N * N, return the same array enlarged 4 times, that is (test 2):

N = 2
#.  --> ##..
           ##.. 
.#  --> ..## 
           ..##

Hello,
This sentence is a little confusing : "This string M should be output by multiplying each character by 4". However, I don't have any substituteðŸ˜¢. But the tests are clear so I managed to understand your game.

Thank you.
I changed the text in the Goal section.
I don't know if the Goal section sentences are now easy to understand, but from now on, I want to try to write sentences that are as easy to understand as possible.(*'Ï‰'*)

Thank you.
The problem statement was very clear and helpful.
I didn't have the idea to put the test case figure on the problem statement, so it was very helpful.
From now on, if a problem is difficult to understand, I will try to make it easier to understand by putting the test case solution on the problem statement.

Thank you.
I have fixed the text.

I think it is more interesting and easier to understand to repackage the problem as a "photocopier" / "graphic design app" problem. You know, you don't always have to write it in the most straight-forward way :wink:

(It will be interesting to adapt the test cases too e.g. a pixelated cartoon face magnifier, but it will be too much work, haha.)

For example, Goal section may be rewritten like this (and other sections have to be adapted accordingly too):

You have drawn some pixelated art for your client, and they have asked you to magnify your art so that it becomes double in size. That means, each pixel used or unused (represented by {{#}} and {{.}} respectively) will be magnified as 4 pixels (i.e. height of 2 x width of 2, please refer to the example below). Please write the code to do the magnification for you.

Just a suggestion and you don't have to follow exactly :)

Thank you.
The way you wrote the problem statement was very helpful.
I tried to make ASCII art of emoticons [((+_+))('â—‡')('_'), etc.] and change it to a question that expands, but when I put it on the question text, the display shifted and some parts were too big to understand, so this time I kept the question simple.
I am very grateful to you for giving me a very good idea and for deepening my knowledge of ASCII art.(*'Ï‰'*)

Thank you for your reply :D

In the goal section if you need monospace text, you use ` ` to enclose it. For example:
`#. --> ##..
##..
.# --> ..##
..##`

Oh, it worked so well!
Thank you!
If I can use monospaced fonts, maybe I can get a problem with a program that enlarges small sized ASCII art! (Like the problem of enlarging the ASCII art of numbers...)
Thanks for sharing that good info!(*'Ï‰'*)
